title: Summer 2021 Shiny App Tutorial: Fingerprint Minutiae Movement by Examiner and Print
description:
A tutorial on how to use the interactive data visualization app I created during
my Summer 2021 research experience, which depicts fingerprint minutiae movement
by examiner and print
contents:
Introduction
In this blog, I’m going to walk through how to use and understand the Shiny app
I created during my Summer 2021 research experience. If you’re unfamiliar with
Shiny apps, they are web applications created using R where you can show your
data analyses and visualizations. And if you’re unfamiliar with the research I
did in Summer 2021, you can read my blog about it
here.
Finding My Shiny App
There are a couple different ways to access my Shiny app: via
this hyperlink,
typing in asluby.shinyapps.io/Minutiae-Movement
into your search bar, or typing in bit.ly/fingerprintimputation
into your search bar. Regardless, they should all take you to the same place.
Scatterplot of Fingerprint Minutiae Markings
I am not able to replicate my entire Shiny app on my website, but I will try my
best to replicate the visualizations found on the app. When you first open the
app, you will see the following scatterplot:



This scatterplot displays all the markings forensic fingerprint examiners make
when they examined a latent and exemplar print to determine if they are matches,
or from the same individual, in this White Box study conducted by the FBI. Due
to privacy reasons, we aren’t allowed to view the fingerprints the examiners
looked at, but if we imagine a Cartesian plane on top of the fingerprints and
markings, this is exactly what the scatterplot is, just without the fingerprints.
The points represent the markings the examiners made in the Comparison and
Analysis stages. The hexagons behind the points are a way to show the density of
markings in an area. A darker hexagon represents an area with a lot of markings
across the examiners, and a lighter hexagon represents an area with few markings.
We can also think of a darker hexagon as an area where many examiners agree that
there is a unique and notable feature, thus resulting in many markings in that
area; similarly, a lighter hexagon is an area where there may not be many unique
and notable features, and so few examiners mark that area. The lines represent
any “movements” of markings between stages of examination. This is useful for my
research in imputation bias, as this could provide evidence that examiners could
be changing markings to support their own conclusions, especially when they are
given an exemplar print to examine alongside the latent print in the Comparison
stage. The color represents minutiae markings marked in the Analysis stage in
this specific scatterplot. There are different characteristics of a fingerprint
that examiners look for and mark, such as minutiae, delta, core, etc. You can
change which part to highlight by selecting a feature on the left of the Shiny
app under “Feature Type.” Note that this is not possible in the scatterplot
shown here on my blog; this only shows the minutiae feature type. Also note that
in some prints, there may be none of a certain feature type. And finally, you
can also hover your mouse over a marking to see which examiner marked it and at
which stage.
The title of the plot includes the study’s label for the prints examined: M010003.
The “M” in the label lets us know that the latent and exemplar prints are indeed
matches in this case, and the numbers are the unique labels for the latent and
exemplar prints.
Thus, this first scatterplot shows the markings made by several examiners (and
how they are moved) at two different stages of examination on a latent and
exemplar print that are matches. If you want to look at different prints, simply
select a different pair from the drop-down menu at the left of the Shiny app under
“Pair ID.” Note that this is not possible here on my blog; this only shows the
pair “M010003.” Also note that if you pick a pair that begins with “N,” the latent
and exemplar prints are not matches in that case.
Scatterplot of Minutiae Markings by Examiner
Above the scatterplot on the Shiny app ( not on this blog), there are three
tabs. Currently, the “Print” tab is selected. This is the scatterplot shown in
the previous section, and it shows the minutiae marked by all the examiners
who looked at this latent and exemplar print. However, we may be interested in
how each examiner marked the prints. We can do this by selecting the “Examiner”
tab above the scatterplot.



The default scatterplot shown above displays all the same information as the
first scatterplot, but instead of looking at markings by all examiners who looked
at pair M010003, this scatterplot only displays markings by one examiner,
specifically examiner EA1338, on the pair M01003. Here, the hexes and line
segments offer more information on how each examiner marks fingerprints. For
example, notice that there is only one dark hexagon. This demonstrates that the
examiner marked minutiae in areas where few other examiners marked minutiae.
While this doesn’t necessarily mean that the examiners minutiae markings can’t be
trusted, this could be a pattern we look for in the examiner’s other fingerprint
markings. Also notice that there are only 2 line segments. This indicates that
the examiner rarely moved any of their markings between stages. Again, while this
doesn’t mean that the examiner is not susceptible to imputation bias, this is
another pattern we can keep in mind when looking at the examiners’ other print
markings. In general, these scatterplots are a good way to get an idea of
examiners’ patterns when marking prints. You can change which examiner’s
scatterplot you want to see by selecting a different examiner from the drop-down
menu under “Examiner ID” at the left of the Shiny app.
The examiners will change when you change the pair ID because different
examiners viewed different fingerprints in this study. Currently, there is no
great way of looking at one examiner’s scatterplot across different prints. When
designing this app, I chose to have it centered around being easier to compare
markings across different prints, and not across one examiner.
Summary of Print Conclusions
The last tab above the scatterplot on the Shiny app ( not on this blog) is
the “Summary” tab. This gives a table depicting the conclusions of the examiners’
findings in this study. Below is the summary table for the pair ID M010003.

% Correct
% No Value
% Inconclusive
% Change in Value
% Very Easy
% Easy
% Moderate
% Difficult
% Very Difficult
# Examiners
1
100
0
0
0
13.33
46.67
33.33
6.67
0
15
The first column is simply the number of rows, which should just be \(1\) for every
summary table. The second column is the percent of examiners who got the
conclusion correct (i.e., they correctly identified the prints as matches or
non-matches). In this specific summary table, \(100\%\) of the examiners correctly
identified this pair as matches. The third column is the percent of examiners who
identified the print as “No Value,” which means that they felt that the latent
print “is not of value for individualization and contains no usable friction ridge
information.” In this specific summary table, \(0\%\) of the examiners identified
the latent print as “No Value.” The fourth column is the percent of examiners who
were inconclusive about their determinations. “Inconclusive” means that “[t]he
comparison [determined] that neither individualization nor exclusion is possible.”
In this specific summary table, \(0\%\) of the examiners were inconclusive about
their results. The fifth column is the percent of examiners who changed their
conclusions between the analysis and comparison stages. For example, an examiner
might identify a latent print as “VEO,” which means that “the impression is of
value for exclusion only and contains some friction ridge information that may be
appropriate for exclusion if an appropriate exemplar is available.” However, after
the comparison stage, the examiner might change their conclusion to “VID,” which
means “that the impression is of value and is appropriate for potential
individualization if an appropriate exemplar is available.” I’ve included this in
the summary table because this could be potential evidence of imputation bias –
especially with a switch from NV (No Value) or VEO (Value for Exclusion Only) to
VID (Value for Identification) because NV/VEO means that the latent print is not
appropriate for individualization. In this specific summary table, we can see
that \(0\%\) of the examiners had a change in value across stages. The next five
columns (columns six through ten) are the percentage of examiners who picked each
comparison difficulty. In this specific summary table, \(13.33\%\) examiners found
the comparison very easy, \(46.67\%\) easy, \(33.33\%\) moderate, \(6.67\%\) difficult,
and \(0\%\) very difficult. And finally, the last column shows the number of
examiners total in the study that looked at that specific latent and exemplar
print. In this specific summary table, \(15\) examiners looked at this specific
pair M010003.
I’ve included this summary table because it gives a good birds-eye view of how
examiners performed on this pair of prints. For pair M010003, the general
conclusion appears to be that it was an “easier” comparison, and every examiner
got it right. With other pairs, we could potentially use the table to find
evidence of imputation bias, such as the “\(\%\) Change in Value” column or “\(\%\)
Correct” column. To view the summary table of other pairs, simply select a
different pair from the drop-down menu under “Pair ID” at the left of the Shiny
app.
Conclusion
This Shiny app was designed as part of my Summer 2021 research looking at
imputation bias in the forensic fingerprint examination process. The scatterplots
and tables show movement and changes in minutiae markings between stages, which
is evidence of imputation bias. In general, however, my goal was to create an
easy, visual way to represent and understand the idea of “imputation bias.” If
you have any further questions, please feel free to reach out to me.

title: Movement of Tenants Evicted from Buildings with Highest Eviction Filing Rates
description:
An introduction to my Summer 2022 internship experience with the Eviction Lab
on better understanding eviction practices in Philadelphia, PA.
contents:
Introduction
In Philadelphia, 25 addresses have accounted for 8.6 percent of all eviction
filings in the county from 2016 to 2020. Meanwhile, other buildings in the
neighborhood file few evictions despite serving tenants with similar socioeconomic
backgrounds. The two current contending theories for these “top evictor” buildings
are: 1) abusive management or 2) buildings of last resort. Abusive management is
the idea that property managers may be too quick to file evictions. If, however,
“top evictors” are serving as buildings of last resort, then the high eviction
rates could be explained by the tenants that are selecting into these buildings.
While the tenantry of top evictors may have similar socioeconomic characteristics
as the tenantry of more stable buildings, tenant self-selection may be selecting
on observable characteristics associated with housing instability.
This research brief examines the mobility of renters in Philadelphia County in
and out of these top evictor buildings since 2016. The analysis aims to understand
why these buildings have such high eviction filing rates, as forced mobility is
disruptive and traumatizing for renters.
Data and Methods
This analysis makes use of the 5-year American Community Survey (ACS) data
from 2015-2019 for the data sets on race, median household income, median gross
rent, and college degree. The Eviction Lab collected data on the top 25 buildings
and zip codes with the highest eviction filing rates in Philadelphia County, PA,
as well as data on mobility to and from select addresses. An eviction filing refers
to any non-commercial eviction (i.e., residential housing not occupied by a business)
case for which we observe a court record.
Using Philadelphia County census tract shapefiles
found on Open Data Philly, we clustered the census
tracts by race, median household income, median gross rent, and college degree
using Latent Profile Analysis. Using a “VVV model” (varying volume, varying
shape, and varying orientation) with six clusters, the model returned a lower BIC
value (-7785.103) than other models and almost all other numbers of clusters.
Clustering allows us to group census tracts with similar races, incomes, rents,
and college degrees. We then combined the clustered data with the top evictor
buildings (geocoded with QGIS) in order to discover if the buildings are clustered
in a way that is different from low eviction buildings.
To analyze mobility flows across numerous buildings and zip codes, we incorporated
address data from Infutor. We identified the most recent moves before and after
living in a top evictor building and/or zip code from the Infutor data. We also
found buildings nearby with similar demographics but lower eviction rates using data.
Using the epiflows
package in R, we then created and compared network graphs for each property and
zip code with the data. The buildings or zip codes serve as nodes, and edges
represent a shared tenant. All plots can be accessed at this interactive data visualization app.
Results
Across the top 25 top evictor buildings, we find that most of the top evictor
buildings are found in areas with lower median household income and lower percentage
of White residents. We also find that almost all the zip codes containing top
evictor buildings are found among the top 25 zip codes with the highest eviction
filing rates. Our analysis thus suggests that eviction filings are deeply linked
with race and poverty.
Mapping the network graphs of top evictors, “control” buildings, and zip codes
allows us to compare general mobility patterns across the different areas.
Preliminary research shows that the top evicting buildings’ network graphs do not
differ significantly from their low-evicting neighbors. Our analysis suggests that
because these network graphs do not differ, then these top evictor buildings are
not serving as buildings of last resort.
While our analysis does not show that “abusive management” is the cause of the
high eviction rates in these top evictor buildings, it is our best guess given
the patterns that we are seeing. Thus, the lab is following up by collaborating
with a team of legal aid providers, who will be doing interviews with tenants of
top evictor buildings to learn more about management practices there. Understanding
what differentiates these top evictors from their seemingly similar neighbors
would give policymakers leverage in reducing the toll of mass evictions on their
communities. If abusive management is in fact the case in these top evictors, then
top-down enforcement actions may be effective at reducing top evictors’ contribution
to city-level eviction rates.
Acknowledgements
I would like to thank the Lang Center for Civic and Social Responsibility
for fully funding this experience and allowing me to work with the Eviction Lab.
I would also like to thank the Eviction Lab for allowing me to intern at their
lab this past summer. I would especially like to thank Carl Gershenson for being my
mentor throughout this project.
References
Desmond, Matthew. Evicted: Poverty and Profit in the American City. Crown Publishers, 2016.
Desmond, Matthew, et al. “Forced Relocation and Residential Instability among
Urban Renters.” Social Service Review, vol. 89, no. 2, June 2015, pp. 227–262.,
https://doi.org/10.1086/681091.
Badger, Emily. “When the Best Available Home Is the One You Already Have.” The
New York Times, The New York Times, 27 May 2022,
https://www.nytimes.com/2022/05/27/upshot/housing-market-slow-moving.html.

title: Imputation Bias in Forensic Fingerprint Examinations
description:
An introduction to my Summer 2021 research with Professor Amanda Luby on
imputation bias in minutiae markings by fingerprint examiners.
contents:
Introduction
Imputation is the process of replacing missing data with substituted values. In
the forensic fingerprint examination process, this bias could come in during the
stage of comparing two potential matching prints. Examiners are shown the latent
and exemplar prints at the same time during this stage, and there is evidence of
minutiae movement, addition, and/or deletion during this stage. In my Summer 2021
research, I explored patterns in these movements in order to identify potential
imputation bias in the forensic fingerprint examination process.
Methods
In order to explore minutiae movement across variables such as examiners, prints,
and feature types, I created an interactive visualization app
as part of my Summer 2021 research with Professor Amanda Luby.
The app allows you to select pairs of prints via the Pair ID drop-down menu. Options
include mates (variables starting with “M”) and non-mates (variables starting with
“N”). The app also allows you to specify an examiner. On the right, the app displays
the minutiae markings of all the examiners who looked at the pair of prints (“Print”
tab), or the minutiae markings of the specific examiner (“Examiner” tab), or the
summary of the analysis of the prints (“Summary” tab). In the Print and Examiner
tabs, each point represents a minutiae marking by an examiner. Lines represent changes
in their markings between stages of examination. Hexes represent the concentration
of markings, where dark represents a higher concentration of markings in the area.
The Summary tab displays how many examiners looked at the pair of prints; which
percentage of the examiners were correct, were inconclusive, changed minutiae markings;
and the difficulty each examiner ranked the pair of prints.
Results and Discussion
Although moving minutiae can occur for a variety of reasons, imputation bias is
still prevalent when there are changes in minutiae. The concern with moving minutiae
is that examiners could be doing so in order to confirm their preliminary conclusions.
For example, as shown by my app, examiners tend to move more minutiae in mated pairs,
indicating that they may be changing more pre-marked minutiae from their first stage
of examination in order to validate their individualization decisions. Additionally,
examiners who viewed the same latent print used in two different pairs have different
preliminary markings, as well as different minutiae movements in the Comparison
stage. This indicates that despite the use of the same latent print in both pairs,
examiners still mark different minutiae, and then choose to move them differently
in the Comparison stage. The different minutiae movements indicates imputation bias,
as they are choosing to move minutiae based on the exemplar print it is paired with.
Many of the minutiae movement occur due to a lack of standardized procedure in the
forensic fingerprint examination process. For example, more deletions might occur
in the Comparison stage at an agency where there is a minimum minutiae requirement;
examiners might be unnecessarily marking minutiae in order to hit the minimum, and then
later deleting the ones that are not helpful. Imputation bias can lead to misidentifications,
which can be very harmful in large, prominent criminal cases. Finally, as previous
papers have mentioned, there should be a rigorously defined, standard forensic fingerprint
examination ACE-V process (Ulery et al., 2015). Many of the examiners, in the White
Box study, stated that exclusions and inconclusive prints were more difficult when
they had to mark minutiae (which they were not required to do so in the Black Box
study) (Ulery et al., 2015). This indicates that examiners do not necessarily have
to mark minutiae in a standardized way. However, if they did, there might be more
transparency in the process, which is particularly important when errors occur.
In the studies, the consequences of making a false identification (or exclusion)
are insignificant, but in true casework, the consequences could change many people’s
lives for the worst.
Terminology
Latent print - An impression of the friction skin of the fingers or palms of the
hands that has been transferred to another surface. These prints are typically lifted
from crime scenes and are usually not of the highest quality.
Exemplar print - A print of the fingers and/or palms deliberately taken from an
individual for record-keeping purposes. Since these prints are collected under ideal
circumstances, they are usually high quality.
Minutiae - Major features of a fingerprint image; they are used in the matching
of fingerprints.
Mates - Two prints that came from the same source.
Non-mates - Two prints that did not come from the same source.
ACE-V process - Method used to reach a determination on each print. ACE-V stands
for Analysis, Comparison, Evaluation, and Verification.
Analysis: The examiner assesses the latent print to determine if it
can be used for comparison. This step involves the preliminary assessment of
several factors like the surface material, the substance of the print itself,
and/or minutiae.
Comparison: The examiner is shown both the exemplar and a latent print.
The exemplar print may come from searching through the Automated Fingerprint Identification
System (AFIS) or some other fingerprint database. The examiner analyses characteristic
attributes of both prints and identifies conformities between the exemplar and
the latent prints.
Evaluation: The examiner decides if the prints are from the same source
(identification or individualization), different sources (exclusion), or are
inconclusive.
Verification: If an identification is made, the conclusion must be verified
by another fingerprint examiner.

References
Ulery, B. T., Hicklin, R. A., Buscaglia, J., and Roberts, M. A. (2011). Accuracy
and reliability of forensic latent fingerprint decisions. Proceedings of the National
Academy of Sciences, 108(19):7733–7738.
Ulery, B. T., Hicklin, R. A., Roberts, M. A., and Buscaglia, J. (2014). Measuring
what latent fingerprint examiners consider sufficient information for individualization
determinations. PlOS ONE, 9(11):e110179.
Ulery, B. T., Hicklin, R. A., Roberts, M. A., and Buscaglia, J. (2015). Changes
in latent fingerprint examiners’ markup between analysis and comparison. Forensic
Science International, 247:54–61.
